column.name: [objID]
column.summary: ID number in PPP (Picture-Processing Package) catalog.

column.name: [CNOC2sp]
column.summary: CNOC2 spectrum number. Spectrum name. The last 4 characters denote mask number, (A,B,C) and spectrum number (e.g. A034), the first 2 numbers denote field numbers (same as (1)). Note that for objects with multiple observations only one of the spectrum IDs is listed (usually the one with the highest redshift reliability (Rval) value).

column.name: [Sc]
column.summary: Spectral class. Spectroscopic classification: 0 = object not targeted for spectroscopy 2 = elliptical spectrum 4 = intermediate-type spectrum 5 = emission-line spectrum 6 = active galactic nuclei 77 = star 88 = unknown 99 = slit but no spectrum (object too faint)

column.name: [w_z]
column.summary: Redshift weight. An important feature of the catalog is the various weights computed to allow the sample to be used as a complete sample. A detailed description of the weights are given in the paper. The primary weight is the magnitude weight Wm (prefixed w_ in the table). The subsidiary weights modify the magnitude weight Wm as follows: W(tot) = Wm * Wxy * Wc * Wz, where Wxy=geometric weight, Wc=color weight, and Wz=redshift weight. Note that each filter has its own Wm, Wxy and Wc. However, Wz, which is model dependent, is determined only for the R filter.

column.name: [Ice]
column.summary: Cousins I color aperture magnitude error. Color aperture magnitude error. This is the magnitude error within the aperture used to determine the color of the object. An approximate uncertainty in the color between any two filters can be derived by adding the two color aperture errors in quadrature.

column.name: [w_Imag]
